When reporting the information for ESRS 2 SBM-3 section 48, the company shall disclose the following:   (a) Whether and how actual or potential consequences for employees in the value chain, as identified under ESRS 2 IRO-1 Description of the process for identifying and assessing significant consequences, risks, and opportunities i) depend on or are connected to the company's strategy or business models and ii) serve as a basis for adjustments to the company's strategy and business model, and   (b) how the company's significant risks and opportunities arising from consequences for, and dependencies on, employees in the value chain relate to the company's strategy and business models.   11. When the company reports under the requirements of ESRS 2 SBM-3 section 48, the company shall disclose whether all employees in the value chain who could be significantly affected by the company, including through consequences related to the company's own operations and value chain, including through its products or services, as well as through its business relationships, are included in the information provided under ESRS 2. Additionally, the company shall provide the following information:   (a) A brief description of the types of employees in the value chain who could be significantly affected by the company, including consequences related to the company's own operations and value chain, including through its products or services, as well as through its business relationships, and whether they are:   i. employees working at the company's facilities but who are not part of the own workforce, that is, who are not self-employed or employees from staffing agencies (as covered by ESRS S1),   ii. employees working for earlier stages in the company's value chain (for example, working in the extraction of metals or minerals or harvesting raw materials, refining, manufacturing or other forms of processing),   iii. employees working for later stages in the company's value chain (for example, working in logistics or transportation or who are franchisees or retailers),   iv. employees working in a joint venture or special company which the reporting company is part of,   v. employees (who fall into the above categories or others) who are particularly hard-hit by negative consequences either due to group affiliation or the specific context, such as union members, migrant workers, domestic workers, women, or youth.   (b) Any areas (countries or other regions) or raw materials where there is a significant risk of child labor or forced labor among employees in the company's value chain.   (c) Whether significant negative consequences occur and whether they are common or systematic in the contexts in which the company operates, makes purchases, or has business relationships (for example, child labor or forced labor in the raw material supply chain in certain countries and regions) or whether they are due to individual events (for example, an industrial accident or oil spill) or specific business relationships. Here, consequences that may arise for employees in the value chain due to the transition to a greener and climate-neutral operation should also be considered. This could involve consequences related to innovations and reorganizations, closure of mines, increased extraction of minerals needed for the transition to a sustainable economy, and manufacturing of solar panels.   (d) If there are significant positive consequences, a brief description of the activities that give rise to positive consequences (such as new purchasing practices or skill development for employees in the supply chain), for example, that the company provides the workforce with opportunities for new employment or further training as part of a just transition, as well as what types of employees in the value chain are affected or may be positively affected. The company may also provide information on whether the positive effects occur in specific countries or regions.   (e) Any significant risks and opportunities for the company that depend on the consequences for, and dependencies on, employees in the value chain.   12. When the company describes which main types of employees in the value chain are affected or could potentially be negatively affected according to the materiality assessment described in ESRS 2 IRO-1, the company shall disclose whether and how it has concluded that certain employees who meet certain criteria work in certain contexts or with a certain type of work tasks may run a greater risk of harm.   13. The company shall disclose whether any of the significant risks and opportunities that depend on consequences for, and dependencies on, employees in the value chain may have effects on certain specific groups (such as certain age groups, employees in a particular factory or country) rather than on all employees in the value chain.

The disclosure required under point 100 shall, in accordance with applicable privacy legislation, include information on work-related discrimination based on gender, ethnic affiliation, nationality, religion or belief, disability, or any other form of discrimination that has affected internal and/or external stakeholders during the reporting period. Harassment is counted as a specific form of discrimination.  103. The company shall provide information on the following: (a) The total number of cases of discrimination, including harassment, that have been reported during the reporting period. (b) The number of complaints filed through channels for individuals in the company's own workforce to raise issues (including grievance mechanisms) and, where applicable, to the national contact points for multinational enterprises within the OECD relating to the issues defined in point 2 of this standard, excluding those already reported in a above. (c) The total amount of fines, penalties, and compensations for the incidents and complaints reported above, and a reconciliation of these amounts against the most relevant figure stated in the financial statements. (d) Contextual information as necessary to understand the data and how it has been compiled.  104. The company shall report the following information on identified cases of serious consequences and incidents related to human rights (such as forced labor, human trafficking, or child labor): (a) The number of serious human rights incidents linked to the company's employees during the reporting period, including a statement of how many of these relate to cases of non-compliance with the UN Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights, the ILO Declaration on Fundamental Principles and Rights at Work, or the OECD Guidelines for Multinational Enterprises. (b) The total amount of fines, penalties, and compensations for damages arising in connection with the incidents described in paragraph a above, along with a reconciliation of the amounts against the most relevant figure in the financial statements.

19. The company shall disclose what general procedures it has for contacts with affected communities and their representatives regarding actual and potential consequences for them.  20. The purpose of this disclosure requirement is to provide understanding of whether and how the company, as part of the due diligence process, is in contact with affected communities, their legitimately designated representatives, or credible intermediaries regarding significant, actual or potential, positive and/or negative consequences that affect, or may affect, them and whether and how the perspectives of the affected communities are taken into account in the company's decision-making process.  21. The company shall indicate whether and how the perspectives of affected communities are considered in the company's decisions and actions to manage actual and potential consequences for the communities. The company shall, if appropriate, explain: (a) whether contacts with affected communities or their legitimately designated representatives occur directly or through credible intermediaries who are familiar with their situation, (b) at what stage contact is made, what type of contacts are involved, and how often such contacts are made, (c) which function and which highest position within the company is operationally responsible for ensuring that these contacts take place and that the results from them are taken into account in the company's decisions, (d) how the company evaluates the appropriateness of its contacts with affected communities and, where appropriate, the agreements or outcomes that arise from those contacts.  22. Where applicable, the company shall specify what it is doing to gain an understanding of the perspectives of such affected communities that may be at particularly high risk of being impacted by consequences and/or are marginalized, as well as of specific groups within those communities, such as women and girls.  23. If the affected communities are indigenous peoples, the company shall also disclose how it considers and ensures that their specific rights are respected in the stakeholder engagement strategy, including their right to free, prior, and informed consent regarding i) their cultural, intellectual, religious, and spiritual rights, ii) activities that affect their land and territories, and iii) legislative or administrative measures that affect them. Regarding contacts with indigenous peoples, the company shall also specifically state whether and how indigenous peoples have been able to express their views on the forms and conditions of such contacts (for example, regarding determining what issues will be discussed and how and when those contacts shall take place).  24. If the company cannot disclose the information required above because it has no procedures for contacts with affected communities, this shall be stated. The company may provide a timeline for when it plans to implement such procedures.

The company shall provide the following information about the composition and diversity of its management, executive, and supervisory bodies: (a) The number of executive and non-executive members. (b) Representation of employees and other workers. (c) Experience relevant to the company's sectors, products, and geographical locations. (d) Percentage by gender and other aspects of diversity that the company takes into account. The company shall provide the following information about the roles and responsibilities of its management, executive, and supervisory bodies: (a) The identity of the management, executive, and supervisory bodies (e.g., a steering committee or similar) or individual persons within an organ responsible for overseeing impacts, risks, and opportunities. (b) How each organ's or individual persons' responsibilities for impacts, risks, and opportunities are reflected in the company's directives, board mandate, and other related policies. (c) A description of the management's role in the governance processes, controls, and procedures used for monitoring, managing, and supervising effects, risks, and opportunities, including i. whether this role is delegated to a specific position or committee at the management level and how oversight of this position or committee is exercised, ii. information about reporting lines to the management, executive, and supervisory bodies, iii. whether specific controls and procedures are applied to managing impacts, risks, and opportunities and, if so, how they are integrated with other internal functions, and (d) how the management, executive, and supervisory bodies and the highest executive management exercise oversight over the establishment of goals related to significant impacts, risks, and opportunities, and how they monitor progress toward those goals.  23. The first is to provide an understanding of all the measures and initiatives through which the company seeks to (a) prevent, mitigate, or remedy negative significant impacts on consumers and/or end-users and/or (b) achieve positive significant impacts for consumers and/or end-users. The second is to provide understanding of how the company addresses significant risks and leverages significant opportunities concerning consumers and/or end-users.  30. The company shall provide a summary description of the action plans and resources it has for managing its significant impacts, risks, and opportunities related to consumers and employees in the value chain according to ESRS 2 MDR-A Actions and resources concerning significant sustainability issues.  31. Regarding significant impacts, the company shall describe (a) what measures are planned or ongoing to prevent, mitigate, or remedy significant negative impacts on consumers and/or end-users, (b) whether and how it has taken actions to provide or facilitate remedies in relation to an actual significant impact, (c) what additional measures or initiatives it has whose primary purpose is to contribute to better social impacts for consumers and/or end-users, and (d) how it follows up and controls that these measures and initiatives achieve the intended results for consumers and/or end-users.  32. With respect to point 28, the company shall describe (a) the processes through which it identifies what measures are needed and appropriate to counter each actual or potential negative impact on consumers and/or end-users, (b) its approach to taking action for specific negative impacts on consumers and/or end-users, such as actions related to the company's product design, marketing, or sales practices, including whether larger collaborations within the industry or with other relevant parties are needed, and (c) how it ensures that there are procedures to remedy or facilitate remedies for any significant negative impacts and that these procedures are effective concerning performance and results.  33. Regarding significant risks and opportunities, the company shall describe (a) what measures are planned or ongoing to reduce significant risks arising from the company's impacts on, and dependencies on, consumers and/or end-users and how it follows up the effectiveness in practice, and (b) what measures are planned or ongoing to leverage significant opportunities for the company concerning consumers and/or end-users.  34. The company shall report whether and how it ensures that its own business practices do not cause or contribute to significant negative impacts on consumers and/or end-users, for example, where applicable, its practices for marketing, sales, or use of personal data. The company may, for instance, report how it manages conflicts between preventing or mitigating significant negative impacts and other business needs.  35. In preparing this disclosure, the company shall consider whether serious human rights issues and incidents connected to consumers and/or end-users have been reported and, if so, provide information about these.  36. If the company evaluates the effectiveness of a measure by establishing a target by disclosing the information required under point 32 c, the company shall consider ESRS 2 MDR-T Monitoring the effectiveness of policies and measures through targets.  37. The company shall report what resources it allocates for managing the significant impacts it causes, with information that enables users to understand how it manages the significant impacts it causes.

3. The company shall disclose the general basis for the preparation of its sustainability statements.  4. The purpose of this disclosure requirement is to provide an understanding of how the company prepares its sustainability statement, including the scope of consolidation, information about the value chain at previous and subsequent stages, and, where applicable, whether the company has used any of the options for omitting information referred to in paragraphs d and e of the following point.  5. The company shall provide the following disclosures: (a) Whether the sustainability statement has been prepared on a consolidated or individual basis. (b) For consolidated sustainability statements: i. confirmation that the scope of consolidation is the same as for the financial reports, or if applicable, an explanation that the reporting company is not required to prepare financial reports or when the reporting company prepares consolidated sustainability reporting in accordance with Article 481 of Directive 2013/34/EU, and ii. if applicable, information about which subsidiaries included in the consolidation are exempt from individual or consolidated sustainability reporting in accordance with Articles 19a.9 or 29a.8 of Directive 2013/34/EU. (c) The extent to which the sustainability statement covers the company's value chain at previous and subsequent stages (see ESRS 1 section 5.1 Reporting companies and the value chain). (d) Whether the company has used the option to omit certain information relating to intellectual property rights, know-how, or results of innovation (see ESRS 1 section 7.7 Confidential and sensitive information and Information on intellectual property rights, know-how, or results of innovation). (e) For companies based in an EU member state that allows forthcoming developments or issues under negotiation to be exempted from disclosure requirements, as provided in Articles 19a.3 and 29a.3 of Directive 2013/34/EU, whether the company has taken advantage of this exemption.

30. The company shall disclose its strategies for addressing significant impacts on affected communities and managing the significant risks and leveraging the significant opportunities concerning affected communities, and the appropriateness of these measures.  31. This disclosure requirement has two purposes. The first is to provide an understanding of all the measures and initiatives through which the company seeks to (a) prevent, mitigate or compensate for negative significant impacts on affected communities and/or (b) achieve positive significant impacts for affected communities. The second is to provide understanding of how the company addresses significant risks and leverages significant opportunities concerning affected communities. The company shall provide a summary description of the action plans and resources it has to manage its significant impacts, risks, and opportunities related to affected communities in accordance with ESRS 2 MDR-A Actions and resources regarding significant sustainability issues.  32. Regarding significant impacts, the company shall describe (a) what actions are planned or ongoing to prevent or mitigate significant negative impacts on affected communities, (b) whether and how it has taken measures to provide or facilitate compensation concerning an actual significant impact, (c) what additional measures or initiatives it has whose primary purpose is to achieve positive impacts for affected communities, and (d) how it follows up and ensures that these actions and initiatives deliver the intended results for affected communities.  33. Regarding point 29, the company shall describe (a) the processes through which it identifies what measures are necessary and appropriate in response to a specific actual or potential negative impact on affected communities, (b) its strategy for taking action on specific negative impacts on communities, for example, measures related to the company’s procedures for land acquisition, land use planning, construction work, and operational and closure practices, as well as whether broader collaboration within the industry or with other relevant parties is needed, and (c) how it ensures that there are procedures for compensation or facilitating compensation in the event of any significant negative impacts and that these procedures are appropriate concerning execution and results.  34. Regarding significant risks and opportunities, the company shall describe (a) what actions are planned or ongoing to reduce the significant risks arising from the impacts the company causes on affected communities and the company's dependence on affected communities and how it follows up the appropriateness in practice, and (b) what actions are planned or ongoing to leverage significant opportunities for the company concerning affected communities.  35. The company shall disclose whether and how it ensures that its own business practices do not cause or contribute to significant negative impacts on affected communities, for example, where relevant, concerning the company’s procedures for land use planning, land acquisition and land exploitation, financing, extraction or production of raw materials, use of natural resources, and management of environmental impact. The company may, for example, disclose how it manages conflicts between preventing or mitigating significant negative impacts and other business needs.  36. The company shall also report if serious human rights issues and incidents related to affected communities have been reported, and if so, provide details about these.  37. When the company provides the information required under point 31 c, it should consider ESRS 2 MDR-T Monitoring the appropriateness of policies and actions through objectives if it evaluates an action's effectiveness by establishing a goal.  38. The company shall disclose what resources it allocates for managing the significant impacts it causes, with information that gives users an understanding of how it manages the significant impacts it causes.

30. The company shall provide a mapping of the information disclosed in its sustainability statement regarding the process for due diligence.  31. The purpose of this disclosure requirement is to provide a clearer understanding of the company's process for due diligence concerning sustainability issues.  32. The main aspects and key steps in due diligence mentioned in ESRS 1 chapter 4 Due diligence are linked to a number of overarching and thematic disclosure requirements according to ESRS. The company shall provide a mapping that explains how and where its application of the main aspects and key steps in the due diligence process is reflected in its sustainability statement, so that the company’s actual methods regarding due diligence can be described.  33. This disclosure requirement does not stipulate any specific behavioral requirements regarding due diligence measures, and the requirement does not extend to or alter the role of management.

30. The company shall provide information about the expected financial effects of significant risks and opportunities related to water resources and marine resources.  31. The information required under point 30 is in addition to the information about current financial effects on the entity's financial position, financial results, and cash flows for the reporting period required under ESRS 2 SBM-3 point 48 d.  32. The purpose of this disclosure requirement is to provide an understanding of (a) expected financial effects due to significant risks arising from the consequences and dependencies related to water resources and marine resources and how these risks have (or can reasonably be expected to have) a significant impact on the company’s financial position, financial results, and cash flows in the short, medium, and long term, (b) expected financial effects due to significant opportunities related to water resources and marine resources.  33. The disclosure shall include the following: (a) A quantification of the expected financial effects in monetary terms before considering measures regarding water resources and marine resources or, if this is not possible without undue costs or efforts, qualitative information. No quantification of the financial effects arising from opportunities is required if such disclosure does not meet the qualitative characteristics of useful information included in ESRS 1 Annex B Qualitative characteristics of information. (b) A description of the effects calculated, the consequences and dependencies to which they are related, and when the effects are expected to arise. (c) The critical assumptions and sources used to quantify the expected financial effects, as well as the level of uncertainty in these assumptions.

31. The company shall provide information about its payment terms, particularly regarding late payments to small and medium-sized enterprises.  32. The purpose of this disclosure requirement is to provide insight into the agreed payment terms and the average actual payment time, particularly how this time affects small and medium-sized enterprises, especially regarding late payments to small and medium-sized enterprises.  33. The disclosure according to point 31 shall include information about the following: (a) The average time in days it takes for the company to pay an invoice from the day the calculation of the payment time begins according to the agreement or law. (b) The standard payment period applied by the company, stated in days and broken down by main categories of suppliers, as well as the proportion of its payments made within this payment period. (c) The number of legal proceedings currently outstanding concerning late payments. (d) Additional information necessary to provide sufficient background. If the company has used a representative sample to calculate the data required under point (a), it shall state this and briefly describe the method used.

32. The company shall provide information on the production, use, distribution, commercialization, and import/export of substances of concern and substances that give rise to very high concern in and of themselves, in mixtures, or in products.  33. The purpose of this disclosure requirement is to enable an understanding of how the company impacts health and the environment through substances of concern and substances that give rise to very high concern in and of themselves. The purpose is also to provide an understanding of the company's significant risks and opportunities, including exposure to these substances and risks resulting from changes in regulations.  34. The information required under point 32 shall include the total quantities of substances of concern that are generated or used in production or that are acquired, and that leave the company's facilities as emissions, products, or as parts of products or services, categorized by the main hazard classes of substances of concern.  35. The company shall separately present information regarding substances that give rise to very high concern.

33. The company shall report measurements of its significant impacts on biodiversity and ecosystems.  34. The purpose of this disclosure requirement is to provide an understanding of how the company manages the consequences assessed to be significant in the materiality assessment for biodiversity and ecosystems.  35. If the company has identified facilities located in or near areas with sensitive biodiversity that are negatively affected (see point 19 a), the company shall disclose how many and how large (in hectares) facilities are owned, leased, or managed in or near these protected areas or important areas for biodiversity.  36. If the company has identified significant effects regarding changed land use or consequences for the extent and condition of ecosystems, it may also disclose its land use based on a life cycle analysis.  37. For the data points specified in points 38–41, the company shall consider its own operations.  38. If the company has determined that it directly contributes to factors impacting changed land, freshwater, and/or marine use, the company shall report relevant measurements. The company may disclose measurements that assess (a) land cover change over time (for example, after one or five years) (e.g., due to deforestation or mining), (b) changes over time (for example, after one or five years) in the management of ecosystems (e.g., through intensified agricultural management or use of better management practices or logging), (c) changes in the geographical composition of landscapes (e.g., whether habitats have been fragmented or how ecological connectivity has changed), (d) changes in structural connectivity of ecosystems (e.g., habitat permeability based on physical conditions and how habitat patches are distributed), and (e) functional connectivity (e.g., how well genes or individuals move through land and freshwater as well as marine environments).  39. If the company has determined that it directly contributes to the introduction of invasive alien species, intentionally or unintentionally, the company may report the measures it uses for the introduction and spread of invasive alien species and the risks posed by these invasive alien species.  40. If the company has determined that it causes significant impacts on the state of species, it may report measures it considers relevant. The company may (a) refer to relevant disclosure requirements in ESRS E1, ESRS E2, ESRS E3, and ESRS E5, (b) take into account population size, distribution within specific ecosystems, and extinction risk. These aspects provide an understanding of the state of individual species populations and their relative ability to withstand changes caused by humans or nature, (c) disclose measures that assess changes in the number of individuals of a species within a specified area, (d) disclose measures on species at risk of extinction that assess i. the degree of threat to species and how activities/stresses may affect the degree of threat, or ii. changes in habitat for a threatened species, as a proxy measure for the consequences the company causes for local populations' risk of extinction.  41. If the company identifies significant effects related to ecosystems, it may provide information on the following: (a) Regarding the extent of ecosystems, measures that assess the distribution of an ecosystem without necessarily considering the condition of the area being assessed, such as habitat coverage. For example, forest cover can be a measure of the extent of a type of ecosystem, without accounting for the condition of the ecosystem (e.g., stating the area of land without describing the species variation in the forest). (b) Regarding the condition of ecosystems: i. measures that assess the condition of ecosystems in relation to a predetermined reference condition, ii. measures that assess multiple species within an ecosystem rather than the number of individuals of a single species within an ecosystem (e.g., scientifically recognized indicators for species richness and species presence that measure how the composition of (native) species evolves within an ecosystem compared to a reference condition at the start of the first reporting period, as well as the desired condition specified in the global Kunming-Montreal framework for biodiversity, or, where applicable, an aggregation of the conservation status of species, or iii. measures that reflect structural components of the condition, such as ecological connectivity (i.e., whether habitats are connected to each other).

34. The company shall provide information on the main components of its risk management and internal control system concerning the sustainability reporting process.  35. The purpose of this disclosure requirement is to provide an understanding of the company's processes for risk management and internal control regarding sustainability reporting.  36. The company shall provide the following disclosures: (a) The scope, main elements, and components of the processes and systems for risk management and internal control concerning sustainability reporting. (b) The risk assessment method followed, including the methodology for prioritizing risks. (c) The main risks identified and the strategies to mitigate them, including associated controls. (d) A description of how the company integrates the results of its risk assessment and internal control regarding the sustainability reporting process into relevant internal functions and processes. (e) A description of how the findings referred to in point d are regularly reported to the management, management, and supervisory bodies.

38. The company shall disclose the parts of its strategy that are connected to or affect sustainability issues, the company’s business model, and its value chain.  39. The purpose of this disclosure requirement is to describe the key elements of the company’s overall strategy that are connected to or affect sustainability issues, and the key components of the company’s business model and value chain, to provide an understanding of its exposure to consequences, risks, and opportunities, and where they originate from.  40. The company shall provide the following disclosures regarding the main elements of its overall strategy that are related to or concern sustainability issues: (a) A description of i. significant groups of products and/or services offered, including changes during the reporting period (new/removed products and/or services), ii. significant markets and/or customer groups served, including changes during the reporting period (new/removed markets and/or customer groups), iii. number of employees by geographic area, and iv. if applicable and significant, products and services that are prohibited in certain markets. (b) A breakdown of total revenue, as included in the company’s financial statements (financial reporting), by significant sectors in the ESRS standards (ESRS sectors). When the company provides segment reporting in accordance with the requirements of IFRS 8 Operating Segments in its financial statements, this information on revenues by sector shall be reconciled as much as possible with the information in IFRS 8. (c) A list of the additional significant ESRS sectors beyond those reported in point 40 b, such as activities that generate internal corporate revenue, where the company develops significant activities or where it is or may become linked to substantial consequences. The identification of these additional ESRS sectors should be consistent with how the company has taken them into account when performing its materiality assessment and with how it discloses significant sector-specific information. (d) Where applicable, an explanation that, together with the associated revenues, demonstrates that the company is active in i. the fossil fuel sector (coal, oil, and gas) (i.e., revenues from exploration, mining, extraction, production, processing, storage, refining, or distribution, including transportation, storage, and trading of fossil fuels as defined in Article 2.62 of the European Parliament and Council Regulation (EU) 2018/1999), including a breakdown of revenues from coal, oil, and gas, as well as revenues from economic activities consistent with the taxonomy requirements related to fossil gas in accordance with Article 8.7 a of the Commission Delegated Regulation 2021/2178, ii. chemical production, i.e., that its operations fall under section 20.2 in Annex I to Regulation (EC) No 1893/2006, iii. controversial weapons (anti-personnel mines, cluster munitions, chemical weapons, and biological weapons), and/or iv. cultivation and production of tobacco. (e) Its sustainability-related goals regarding significant groups of products and services, customer categories, geographic areas, and connections with stakeholders. (f) An assessment of its current significant products and/or services as well as significant markets and customer groups in relation to its sustainability-related goals. (g) The elements of the company’s strategy that pertain to or affect sustainability issues, including the main upcoming challenges, critical solutions or projects to be implemented, when relevant to sustainability reporting.  41. If the company is established in an EU member state that allows exemptions from disclosing the information referred to in Article 18.1 a of Directive 2013/34/EU, and if the company has availed itself of this exemption, it may omit the breakdown of revenues by significant ESRS sector required under point 40 b. In this case, the company shall still disclose the list of ESRS sectors that are significant for the company.  42. The company shall provide a description of its business model and its value chain, including (a) its inputs and its strategy for collecting, developing, and securing these inputs, (b) its outputs and outcomes in terms of current and expected benefits for customers, investors, and other stakeholders, and (c) prominent parts of its value chain in earlier and later stages and the company’s position in its value chain, including a description of the main business actors (such as main suppliers, distribution channels to customers, and end users) and their connection to the company. When the company has multiple value chains, the disclosure shall cover the significant value chains.

38. The company shall report on the time-bound and result-oriented goals it has to (a) reduce the negative consequences for consumers and/or end users and/or (b) strengthen the positive consequences for consumers and/or end users and/or (c) manage significant risks and opportunities related to consumers and/or end users.   39. The purpose of this disclosure requirement is to provide understanding of the extent to which the company uses time-bound and result-oriented goals as incentives to reduce the significant negative consequences, and/or strengthen the positive consequences, for consumers and/or end users that it causes and/or manage significant risks and opportunities related to consumers and/or end users and to measure how well it succeeds in this work.   40. The summarized description of the goals for managing the significant consequences, risks, and opportunities related to consumers and/or end users that it causes shall contain the information required by ESRS 2 MDR-T.   41. The company shall state how the process for formulating the goals proceeds, if and how, for example, it consults directly with consumers and/or end users, their legitimately appointed representatives or credible third parties who are aware of their situation regarding (a) formulating the goals, (b) checking whether the company achieves the goals, and (c) determining whether there are any lessons to be learned, or improvements to be made, regarding the company's efforts to reach the goals.

39. The company shall report on the time-bound and results-oriented goals it has to   (a) reduce the negative consequences for affected communities and/or   (b) strengthen the positive consequences for affected communities and/or   (c) manage significant risks and opportunities related to affected communities.  40. The purpose of this disclosure requirement is to provide an understanding of the extent to which the company uses time-bound and results-oriented goals as incentives to reduce the significant negative consequences, and/or strengthen the positive consequences, for affected communities that it causes and/or manage significant risks and opportunities related to affected communities and to measure how well it succeeds in this work.  41. The summarized description of the goals for managing the significant consequences, risks, and opportunities related to affected communities shall include the information required according to ESRS 2 MDR-T.  42. The company shall state how the process for formulating the goals works, if and how it consults directly with the affected communities, their legitimately appointed representatives, or credible agents familiar with their situation regarding   (a) formulating the goals,   (b) checking whether the company achieves the goals, and   (c) determining if there are any lessons to be learned, or improvements to be made, regarding the company's efforts to achieve the goals.

41. The company shall disclose the expected financial effects of significant risks and opportunities arising from consequences related to resource use and circular economy.  42. The information required under point 41 is in addition to the information on current financial effects on the unit’s financial position, financial performance, and cash flows for the reporting period as required by ESRS 2 SBM-3 point 48 d. The purpose of this disclosure requirement is to provide an understanding of (a) expected financial effects due to significant risks arising from significant resource use and consequences and dependencies related to the circular economy and how these risks have or reasonably can be expected to have a significant impact on the company’s financial position, financial performance, and cash flows in the short, medium, and long term, and (b) expected financial effects due to significant opportunities related to resource use and circular economy.  43. The disclosure shall include the following: (a) A quantification of the expected financial effects in monetary terms before considering resource use and measures relating to the circular economy, or, if this is not possible without undue costs or efforts, qualitative information. No quantification of the financial effects arising from opportunities is required if such disclosure does not meet the qualitative characteristics of useful information as outlined in ESRS 1 Annex B Qualitative characteristics of information. (b) A description of the effects calculated, the consequences and dependencies they are related to, and when the effects are expected to occur. (c) The critical assumptions and sources used to quantify the expected financial effects, as well as the sources of and level of uncertainty in these assumptions.

44. The company shall report on what time-limited and results-oriented objectives it has for  (a) reducing the negative consequences for its own workforce and/or  (b) strengthening the positive consequences for its own workforce and/or  (c) managing significant risks and opportunities related to its own workforce.  45. The purpose of this disclosure requirement is to provide an understanding of the extent to which the company uses results-oriented objectives as incentives and to measure how well it manages to  reduce significant negative consequences and/or strengthen positive consequences for its own workforce caused by it and/or to manage significant risks and opportunities related to its own workforce.  46. The summarized description of the objectives for managing the significant consequences, risks, and opportunities related to its own workforce shall include the information required according to ESRS 2 MDR-T.  47. The company shall state how the process for formulating the objectives takes place, whether and how it, for example, consults directly with its own workforce or their representatives regarding  (a) formulating the objectives,  (b) checking whether the company is achieving the objectives, and  (c) determining whether there are any lessons to be learned, or improvements to be made, regarding the company’s efforts to reach the objectives.

54. The company shall report on the disclosure requirements it follows in its sustainability statements.  55. The purpose of this disclosure requirement is to provide an understanding of the disclosure requirements included in the company's sustainability statement and the topics that have been omitted as non-material due to the materiality assessment.  56. The company shall include a list of the disclosure requirements it follows when preparing the sustainability statement, based on the outcome of the materiality assessment (see ESRS 1 [draft], chapter 3), including the page numbers and/or points where the related disclosures can be found in the sustainability statements. This may be presented as a content index. The company shall also include a table of all data points derived from other EU legislation according to the list in Appendix B to this standard, indicating where they can be found in the sustainability statement and including those that the company has assessed as non-material, in which case the company shall indicate "non-material" in the table in accordance with paragraph 35 of ESRS 1.  57. If the company concludes that climate change is not material and therefore omits all disclosure requirements ESRS E1 Climate Change, it shall explain the conclusions in detail in its materiality assessment regarding climate change (see ESRS 2 IRO-2 Disclosure Requirements in ESRS Standards covered by the company's sustainability statements), along with a forward-looking analysis of the circumstances that could lead the company to conclude that climate change is material in the future.  58. If the company concludes that another topic, other than climate change, is not material and therefore omits all disclosure requirements in the corresponding thematic ESRS, it may briefly explain the conclusions in its materiality assessment for the topic.  59. The company shall account for how it has determined which material information to disclose in relation to the consequences, risks, and opportunities it has assessed to be material, including the use of thresholds and/or how it has implemented the criteria in section 3.2 of ESRS Material Issues and the materiality of information.

67. The company shall inform whether its employees receive a sufficient salary and if not, the affected countries and the percentage of employees.  68. The purpose of this disclosure requirement is to provide an understanding of whether all employees at the company receive sufficient salaries in line with prevailing reference salaries or not.  69. The company shall state whether all employees receive sufficient salaries in line with prevailing reference salaries. If this is the case, it is sufficient to state this for the disclosure requirement to be fulfilled and no further information needs to be provided.  70. If not all its employees receive sufficient salaries in line with prevailing reference salaries, the company shall inform about the countries where employees earn less than the prevailing reference salary and the percentage of employees earning less than the prevailing reference salary for each of these countries.  71. The company may also provide the information specified in this disclosure requirement with respect to non-employees in its workforce.

68. When reporting on the legal form of the undertaking according to national legislation under paragraph 24(e)(i), the undertaking can choose from one of the following undertaking structures:   (a) private limited liability undertaking   (b) sole proprietorship   (c) partnership   (d) cooperative   (e) other (please specify based on country specifications for legal forms).   69. When reporting on the NACE code(s) of the undertaking under paragraph 24(e)(ii), NACE codes (Nomenclature statistique des Activités économiques dans la Communauté Européenne) are classifications of economic activities used in the European Union. They provide a standardized framework for classifying economic activities into sectors, enabling comparability and a common understanding among the various EU countries.   70. The NACE code consists of a number of digits ranging from 2 to 5 depending on the level of specificity with which the economic activity is identified. The list of NACE codes can be found in the following document: REGULATION (EC) No 1893/2006.   71. When reporting the number of employees under paragraph 24(e)(v), full-time equivalent (FTE) is the number of full-time positions in an undertaking. It can be calculated by dividing an employee's scheduled hours (total effective hours worked in a week) by the employer's hours for a full-time workweek (total hours performed by full-time employees). For example, an employee who works 25 hours every week for a company where the full-time week is 40 hours represents a 0.625 FTE (i.e. 25/ 40 hours).   72. Headcount is the total number of people employed by the undertaking at a given time.   73. When reporting on the country of primary operations and the location of significant assets under paragraphs 24(e)(vi) and (vii), the undertaking shall disclose this information for each of its sites using the table below (see standard for table- s.16):   74. The geolocation of an undertaking is expected to be a valuable datapoint for stakeholders for the assessment of risks and opportunities connected to the SME, particularly in relation to the sustainability issues of climate change adaptation, water, ecosystems and biodiversity.   75. The geolocation shall be provided in spatial points for single units or polygon points defining the boundaries of a larger, less unit-like site, such as a farm, mine or facility. The undertaking may also provide a cluster of points to allow for the easy identification of the concerned area. The spatial points shall be provided as coordinates, with five decimal places (e.g. 0° 00' 0.036").   76. When disclosing the geolocation of sites owned, leased, or managed, the undertaking shall include the coordinates of the sites in the table shown in paragraph 73. The undertaking may use web mapping tools (e.g. Google Maps, Apple Maps) to identify the coordinates of sites that it owns, leases or manages. The undertaking may also use any appropriate software tools or platforms to further establish the perimeter or area of larger sites.

72. The company shall indicate whether its employees are covered by social protection against income loss in the event of major life events and, if not, in which countries they are not.  73. The purpose of this disclosure requirement is to provide an understanding of whether the company's employees are covered by social protection against income loss in the event of major life events and, if not, in which countries this is the case.  74. The company shall state whether all employees are covered by social protection against income loss, through public insurance or benefits offered by the company, in the following major life events:   (a) Illness.   (b) Unemployment, where the protection applies from the time the employee starts working for the company.   (c) Work-related injuries and acquired disabilities.   (d) Parental leave.   (e) Retirement.   If this is the case, it is sufficient to state this for the disclosure requirement to be met, and no further information needs to be provided.  75. If not all its employees are covered by social protection in accordance with point 72, the company shall also disclose the countries where the employees do not have social protection regarding one or more of the types of events specified in point 72, and for each of these countries, the types of employees who do not have social protection regarding each applicable major life event.  76. The company may also provide the information specified in this disclosure requirement concerning non-employees in its workforce.

73. The company shall apply the content requirements for disclosures according to this provision when it provides information about the measurements it has for each significant sustainability issue.  74. The purpose of this minimum requirement for disclosures is to give an impression of the measurements the company uses to follow up on how effective its actions to manage significant sustainability issues are.  75. The company shall disclose all measurements it uses to assess performance and effectiveness, with regard to a significant impact, risk, or opportunity.  76. The measurements shall include those defined in ESRS, as well as measurements identified on a department-specific basis, whether they are taken from other sources or have been developed by the company itself.  77. For each measurement, the company shall (a) disclose the methods and key assumptions underlying the measurement, including the limitations of the methods used, (b) provide information on whether the measurement according to the measurement is validated by another external body than the insurer and, if so, which body, (c) designate and define the measurements with meaningful, clear, and precise names and descriptions, (d) when currency is specified as a measurement unit, use the currency in which its financial statements are presented.

77. The company shall provide information on the proportion of employees with disabilities.  78. The purpose of this disclosure requirement is to provide understanding of the extent to which there are individuals with disabilities among the company’s employees.  79. The company shall state what proportion of their employees have a disability in accordance with laws that specify which personal data may be collected.  80. The company may report the proportion of employees with disabilities broken down by gender.

78. The company shall apply the content requirements in the disclosures according to this provision when it provides disclosures about the goals it has for each material sustainability issue.  79. The purpose of this minimum requirement for disclosures is to provide an understanding for each material sustainability issue of the following: (a) Whether and how the company monitors the appropriateness of its actions to address material impacts, risks, and opportunities, including the metrics it uses to do so. (b) Measurable time-bound outcome-oriented goals that the company has set to fulfill the purposes of the policy, defined as expected results for people, the environment, or the company concerning material impacts, risks, and opportunities. (c) General progress towards the adopted goals over time. (d) If the company has not established measurable time-bound outcome-oriented goals, whether and how it still tracks the appropriateness of its actions to manage material impacts, risks, and opportunities and measures progress towards achieving the purposes of the policy. (e) Whether and how stakeholders have participated in setting the goals for each material sustainability issue.  80. The company shall disclose the measurable, outcome-oriented, and time-bound goals for material sustainability issues that it has set to assess progress. The organization shall determine the boundaries and applicability of the environmental management system to establish its scope. The organization shall monitor, measure, analyze, and evaluate its environmental performance.   The organization shall establish:   a) what needs to be monitored and measured;   b) the methods that, as appropriate, are needed for monitoring, measuring, analyzing, and evaluating in order to ensure reliable results;   c) criteria and appropriate indicators according to which the organization shall evaluate environmental performance;   d) when monitoring and measuring shall be conducted;   e) when the results from monitoring and measuring shall be analyzed and evaluated. The organization shall establish, implement, and maintain one or more internal audit programs, which include frequency, methods, responsibilities, planning requirements, and reporting of internal audits. When the internal audit program is established, the organization shall consider the significance of the affected processes to the environment, changes that impact the organization, and the results from previous audits. The organization shall:   a) define audit criteria and scope for each audit;   b) select auditors and conduct audits in a manner that ensures the objectivity and independence of the audit process;   c) ensure that audit results are reported to relevant management functions;   The organization shall retain documented information that demonstrates the implementation of the audit program and audit results.

The organization shall establish, implement, and maintain the process(es) needed to meet the requirements in 6.1.1 to 6.1.4. Within the scope of the environmental management system, the organization shall identify potential emergency situations, including those that may have environmental impact. The organization shall maintain documented information regarding: — risks and opportunities that need to be addressed; — the process(es) needed according to 6.1.1 to 6.1.4, to the extent necessary to have confidence that they are performed as planned.

The organization shall plan: a) actions to manage its: 1) significant environmental aspects; 2) binding requirements; 3) risks and opportunities identified in 6.1.1; b) how it will: 1) integrate and implement the actions into the environmental management system processes (see 6.2, section 7, section 8, and 9.1), or other business processes; 2) evaluate whether the actions have had the intended effect (see 9.1). The top management shall review the organization's environmental management system at planned intervals to ensure the continued suitability, adequacy, and effectiveness of the system. The management review shall include consideration of:   a) the status of actions decided during previous management reviews;   b) changes in:   1) external and internal issues that are relevant to the environmental management system;   2) stakeholder needs and expectations, including binding requirements;   3) its significant environmental aspects;   4) risks and opportunities;   c) the extent to which the organization's environmental objectives have been achieved;   d) information on the organization's environmental performance, including trends in terms of:   1) nonconformities and corrective actions;   2) results from monitoring and measurement;   3) compliance with binding requirements;   4) audit results;   e) the adequacy of resources;   f) relevant communication from stakeholders, including complaints;   g) opportunities for continual improvement.   The output of the management review shall include:   — conclusions on whether the environmental management system is still suitable, adequate, and effective;   — decisions related to opportunities for continual improvement;   — decisions regarding the need for changes to the environmental management system, including resources;   — actions, if necessary, when environmental objectives have not been achieved;   — opportunities to improve the integration of the environmental management system into other business processes, if necessary;   — any consequences for the organization's strategic direction.   The organization shall retain documented information that demonstrates the results of management reviews.

The top management shall clearly demonstrate leadership and commitment regarding the environmental management system by: a) taking responsibility for the effectiveness of the environmental management system; b) ensuring that the environmental policy and environmental objectives are established and are compatible with the organization’s strategic direction and conditions; c) ensuring that the requirements of the environmental management system are integrated into the organization’s operational processes; d) ensuring that the environmental management system is provided with necessary resources; e) communicating the importance of leading and managing environmental work effectively and meeting the requirements of the environmental management system; f) ensuring that the environmental management system achieves its intended results; g) leading and supporting individuals so that they contribute to an effective environmental management system; h) promoting continuous improvement; i) providing support to other relevant leaders so that they demonstrate their leadership in a manner that is appropriate within their areas of responsibility. Appropriate measures to manage risks associated with business relationships may sometimes include continuing the business relationship throughout the risk mitigation effort or temporarily suspending it while the risk mitigation work is ongoing. It may also involve terminating the business relationship, e.g., if the company fails to mitigate risks, if the company believes the risks cannot be mitigated, or due to the severity of the negative impact. The company should take into account potential social and economic negative impacts in the decision to terminate the business relationship. In these plans, the company should specify what actions it will take, as well as what it expects from its suppliers, buyers, and other business relationships. PRACTICAL MEASURES a. Designate who will be responsible for developing, implementing, and monitoring these plans. b. Assist or collaborate with relevant business relationships to devise appropriate plans to prevent or mitigate identified negative impacts within reasonable and clearly defined timeframes. The plans should include qualitative and quantitative indicators to define and measure improvements (which are sometimes referred to as improvement plans). ? See question 38 in the appendix. c. Use the company's influence as much as possible to persuade the business relationship to prevent or limit negative impacts or risks. ? See questions 36 and 40 in the appendix. d. If the company does not have sufficient influence, attempt to find ways to increase influence over the business relationship, including through outreach by senior management and through commercial incentives. Collaborate to the greatest possible extent with other stakeholders to build and exercise collective influence, for example through collaborative efforts in industry associations or through cooperation with governments. ? See question 37 in the appendix. e. To prevent potential (future) negative impacts and manage actual impacts, try to build influence in new and existing business relationships, e.g., through policies or codes of conduct, agreements, written arrangements, or the use of market influence. ? See section II, 1.3 and question 36 in the appendix. f. Regarding impacts on human rights, encourage entities that cause or contribute to negative impacts to consult and collaborate with affected or potentially affected rights holders or their representatives in the work of developing and implementing improvement plans. ? See questions 8–11 in the appendix. g. Assist relevant suppliers and other business relationships to prevent or reduce negative impacts or risks, e.g., by providing training, upgrading facilities, or strengthening their management systems, to achieve ongoing improvements. ? See question 38 in the appendix. h. Consider, as a last resort, terminating the cooperation with the supplier or business relationship if a negative impact cannot be prevented or mitigated, if the negative impact is irreparable, if there are no reasonable prospects for change, or if serious negative impacts or risks are identified and the entity causing the impact does not immediately take action to prevent or limit it. The company should, in all plans to terminate the cooperation, also consider how important the supplier or business relationship is to the company, what the legal consequences will be of maintaining or ending the relationship, and how a termination might change the impact in practice. The company should also consider reliable information about what negative social and economic effects the decision to terminate cooperation might have. ? See question 39 in the appendix. i. If a company decides to maintain a business relationship, it should be able to explain what measures it is taking to mitigate risks. It should also be aware of the reputational, financial, or legal risks involved in continuing the collaboration. j. Urge relevant authorities in the country where the impact occurs to act, e.g., through inspections, enforcement, and application of applicable laws and other regulations. ? See box 6.

Gather, when appropriate and possible, relevant information about business relationships with which the company does not have contracts (e.g., subcontractors outside the 'first tier'). Establish processes, either individually or jointly, to assess risks associated with more distant links in the business relationship, including by reviewing existing assessments and collaborating with actors in the intermediary levels of the supply chain and control points to evaluate their due diligence practices in light of this guidance. d. Good to keep in mind

Risk management is about managing uncertainty - i.e., being prepared for things that may potentially occur and affect the business, etc.

”An Event or Circumstance leads to an Effect which in turn has an Impact”

A data breach (Event) resulting in a leak of personal data (Effect) leads to loss of trust and financial damage (Impact).

Purpose

The focus here is on how changes in the external environment affect our organization, specifically the financial consequences for the organization. A potential positive economic impact represents an opportunity, while a potential negative impact represents a risk.

A sustainability topic is considered financially material if it causes or may cause significant financial impact on the company's development in the short, medium, or long term. 

  • Short term (1 year)
  • Medium term (approx. 5 years)
  • Long term (> 5 years)

Purpose

In this view, you conduct your impact analysis, which is the first step in the dual materiality analysis. Here, important sustainability topics are identified, broken down into subtopics, based on your organization and its stakeholders. The outward impact (impact materiality) is the focus, that is, how your organization affects various sustainability topics.

Things to consider

Try to include these different aspects:

  • Impact on people and/or the environment in the short, medium, or long term. Short term (1 year), medium term (approx. 5 years), long term (>5 years)
  • Impact that the organization causes or contributes directly to.
  • Impact that is linked to the organization's operations, its products, and services through its relationships with other organizations. Include the entire value chain, both upstream and downstream, and do not limit it to entered agreements.

Type of impact and stakeholders:

  • Impact can be both positive and negative.
  • Impact can be actual (already occurring) or potential (may occur).
  • Stakeholders are those affected by the topic/subtopic. This can be your own organization, suppliers, customers, society, partners, subsidiaries, among others.
  • Selectable stakeholders are based on a keyword group. Your specific stakeholders must be added as keywords in the group before you select them here.

Assess impact through severity and probability:

  • Negative impact:
    - Scale: how severe is the impact? 
    - Extent: how widespread is the impact?
    - Restorability: how and to what extent is the impact restorable?
    The average of these three parameters becomes the severity level.
    Then assess the probability that the impact will occur (probability = 5 if actual negative impact).
  • Positive impact: 
    - Scale: how severe is the impact?
    - Extent: how widespread is the impact?
    - Note! Restorability is left blank for positive impact.
    The average of these two parameters (scale and extent) becomes the severity level.
    Then assess the probability that the impact will occur (probability = 5 if actual positive impact).
  • When it comes to impact on human rights, severity should be prioritized.

Purpose

This view focuses on evaluating and reassessing risks, creating action plans, and marking what should be included in the internal control plan.

What is expected of me?

  • Click on the plus sign {{ stratsys.Image{id: "a58af7c0-753d-46ef-b276-af2400ced1b1", title: "Image"} }} to add new immediate actions.
  • Click on the wrench {{ stratsys.Image{id: "9e3e9749-0e6d-4f7f-b3f4-af2400cedf91", title: "Image"} }} to modify existing immediate actions.
  • Click on the block {{ stratsys.Image{id: "81ddecd3-0840-4f47-aa8f-af2400ceea5b", title: "Image"} }} to follow up. Follow the instructions in the follow-up window to select a status and write a comment. You will receive assistance from the material on the right side in the follow-up view.

Good to keep in mind

Action plans consist of defined actions that should be taken to control/manage a risk. This may involve, for example, purchasing insurance coverage (risk transfer), implementing temporary rules regarding masks and hand sanitizer in the office (reduction), or entering into partnerships to reduce potential exposure (risk sharing).

When working with net risk, it refers to 'the risk as it stands right now with the actions and control activities we have in place'. 'In place' means exactly this, i.e., it is not planned actions or desired actions, nor so temporary actions that they do not have a lasting effect on our risk exposure. In the view, it corresponds to the parts of the action plan that are marked as complete.

Actions and control activities that do not have a direct connection to how they affect impact and probability are also not helpful to include.
